answers.author: Jacob Foos
answers.text:
When I was with the City of Enid, Oklahoma, we developed a "Shop Enid" campaign.  The City did all of the legwork but we utilized local entities to spread the word about the program.  It was very simple and user friendly but we did not have a system in place to track any metrics of success for the campaign.  We chose to go in another direction after doing a winter holiday launch from November through December, had we stayed with the program we would have looked at ways to track how many people utilized the cards.
http://enid.org/index.aspx?page=982

answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
In Charlottesville, many small businesses use Cardagin, a homegrown app for loyalty programs to replace "buy 10 get 1 free" paper cards that leave us saying, "Where's that card again?" I use it often.
It wouldn't be hard to have the Chamber or other partner link into the app with extra rewards on top of those offered by businesses for loyalty --a spiffy Murrieta Locavore t-shirt or something like that.
Your local businesses could buy this app, or maybe a local developer could make you something similar. http://cardagin.com/

author: Izzy Murguia
text: Does your city have an economic development loyalty or discount business program whereby businesses who choose to take part offer special or discount offers to program members?  I am looking for sample programs developed and operated by city staff or in partnership with the local chamber of commerce. I am interested to hear positive/negative experiences and any other issues related to your program. Thank you for your assistance!
title: Economic Development Shopping Programs
